title: Missing Native Americans (Oneida County Sheriff)

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: Missing Native Americans (Oneida County Sheriff)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

Basic information on all cases (open and closed) of missing American Indian/Alaska Native persons (including juveniles) within your region, from 2000 through 2020; this basic information can include but is not limited to: person name, age, DOB, incident date, case closure date, county/jurisdiction in which person was reported missing.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Urban Indigenous Collective

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Law  Request 110022-57819675
communications.communication:
Re:    Freedom of Information Law request

The Oneida County Sheriff's Office has received your request for records under the Freedom of Information Law on .

The procedure to obtain information is to contact the Oneida County Clerk's Office through the Oneida County Website. You will find the proper form by clicking on the link I have provided below.
https://ocgov.net/departments/county-clerk/
After clicking this link, scroll down on the page to Quick Links and click on Freedom of Information (FOIL) to fill out and submit the form.
Once you have completed and submitted the FOIL request the Clerk's Office will advise our Office of the requested materials.

If you have any difficulties or further inquiries regarding your request, please contact the Oneida County Clerk's Office at 315-798-5776 for guidance.  For any questions specific to our office, please feel free to contact Captain Tim O'Halloran through email TOhalloran@oneidacountysheriff.us<mailto:TOhalloran@oneidacountysheriff.us> or by phone (315)765-2748.

Sincerely,

Molly Ballard
Principal Clerk
Oneida County Sheriff's Office
6065 Judd Road
Oriskany, NY 13424
315-765-2294

communications.subject: Missing Native Americans (Oneida County Sheriff)
communications.communication:
Dear sir or Madam,

In May of 2022, You have made a request to Oneida County. Your request asks, "for Basic information on all cases (open and closed) of any survivors or victims of murdered American Indian/Alaska Native persons (including juveniles) within your region, from 2000 through 2020; this basic information can include but is not limited to: person name, age, DOB, incident date, case closure date, county/jurisdiction in which person was reported missing or murdered." After conducting a diligent search in the possession of Oneida County, we were unable to find any records responsive to your request.

Thank you!
Best regards

Ahmat Adam Djouma
Paralegal Assistant
Oneida County Law Department
800 Park Avenue
Utica, New York 13501
P: 315-266-6142
Ext. 86142

Thank you,

OC FOIL Office

title: FBI Documents Related to Surveillance of Black Lives Matter and Related Groups

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: FBI Documents Related to Surveillance of Black Lives Matter and Related Groups
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

I am requesting access to documents related to the FBI's surveillance or investigation of Black Lives Matter and other related groups. In order to ensure a comprehensive search for responsive records, I am requesting an interagency search for any records that may be held by other law enforcement agencies or government entities.

I would also like to reference the Brennan Center's report entitled "FBI Targets a New Generation of Black Activists," published on September 13, 2017, which highlights the FBI's targeting of Black activists. I will be attaching the article for your reference.

Specifically, I am seeking any records, reports, memoranda, emails, or other documents related to the FBI's surveillance or investigation of Black Lives Matter, including any policies, guidelines, or procedures related to this surveillance or investigation. I am also requesting any communications between the FBI and other law enforcement agencies or government entities related to the surveillance or investigation of Black Lives Matter.

Additionally, I am interested in any records, reports, memoranda, emails, or other documents related to the FBI's surveillance or investigation of any groups or individuals associated with Black Lives Matter or involved in activism related to racial justice, police reform, or other related issues. This may include but is not limited to groups such as the Movement for Black Lives, Campaign Zero, and the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP).

I want to emphasize that I do not consent to the withholding, deletion, or redaction of any responsive records or documents, except in cases where the FBI or any other agency can provide a specific justification for why the records are exempt from disclosure under the Freedom of Information Act. Please provide me with any non-exempt records or documents in their entirety, including any segregable portions that may be released.

I hereby provide notice that any attempt to withhold, redact, or delete responsive records or documents without providing a specific justification for why they are exempt from disclosure will be met with a complaint and legal action to compel the FBI or any other agency to provide access to the requested records in accordance with the Freedom of Information Act.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Good Citizen

requests are processed in the order that they are received. If you have not
received a FOIPA request number, your request is in the process of being
opened at which time it will be assigned a FOIPA request number and

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request: FBI Documents Related to Surveillance of Black Lives Matter and Related Groups
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

I am writing to appeal the response to my Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request regarding Black Lives Matter, FOIPA Request No.: 1589047-000. I am requesting that the FBI conduct a more thorough search and provide all responsive records.

In my initial request, I provided specific key terms and reference points to narrow down the search, yet the response I received stated that there was no attempt made to search for responsive records. This leads me to believe that the search was inadequate in whole, and I request that the FBI conduct a more comprehensive search.

Furthermore, I would like to request an interagency search for any responsive records that may be held by other agencies. As stated in 5 U.S.C. § 552 (a)(3)(C), agencies are required to make reasonable efforts to search for records that are requested, even if the records are not located within the agency. Given the importance and significance of the Black Lives Matter movement, I believe it is reasonable to assume that other agencies may hold responsive records.

In support of my appeal, I would like to cite the case law of Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington v. Executive Office of the President, 658 F. Supp. 2d 217, 225 (D.D.C. 2009), which held that agencies must conduct a search that is reasonably calculated to uncover all responsive documents, rather than a search that is cursory or in bad faith. Additionally, I would like to cite the legal principle of agency discretion, which provides that agencies must conduct their searches in good faith and with due diligence.

I hope that you will reconsider your response to my FOIA request and conduct a more thorough search for responsive records. If you have any questions or require any further information, please do not hesitate to contact me.

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Sincerely,

title: Paul Laxalt

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Paul Laxalt
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

The files of Paul Laxalt (1922-1918), former Nevada governor and US Senator, whose obituary is published here:

https://www.nytimes.com/2018/08/06/obituaries/paul-laxalt.html?rref=collection%2Fsectioncollection%2Fobituaries&action=click&contentCollection=obituaries&region=rank&module=package&version=highlights&contentPlacement=9&pgtype=sectionfront

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Ryan Weisensee

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #1413411-000
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

I wanted to follow up on the following Freedom of Information Act request, copied below, and originally submitted on Aug. 9, 2018. Please let me know when I can expect to receive a response.  You had assigned it reference number #1413411-000.

Thanks for your help, and let me know if further clarification is needed.

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #1413411-000
communications.communication:
Please check the status of your FOIPA Request at http://vault.fbi.gov by clicking on "Check Status of Your FOI/PA Request" on the right side of the page, and follow the instructions below.

Check the Status of Your FOIPA Request
If your FOIPA Number is [1234567-0] please enter [1234567-000] into the system. If your FOIPA Number is [1234567-1] please enter [1234567-001] into the system. If you have any questions about the status of your FOIPA request, please e-mail foipaquestions@ic.fbi.gov.

FIND STATUS OF FOIPA- Request statuses are updated weekly

Please enter the whole FOIPA number-Example: [1234567-000]

FOIPA:
Results will show the Request Number, Case Type and Process Description shown below:
FOIPA:
1234567-000

Case Type:
FOIPA

Process Description (Will display the current progress of the request)
The FBI's FOIPA Program is searching the FBI's indices for potentially responsive documents.
You may be contacted via formal letter for all fees and/or negotiation issues that may apply.

NOTE: Recent requests are entered into the FOIPA database in the order that they are received. Before you can check the status, you must have received correspondence assigning a FOIPA request number and the information transferred to the online database. Status information is updated weekly. If a request has been closed within the last six months the online database will display the following: The FOIPA number entered has been closed, and appropriate correspondence has been sent to the address on file.

Estimated Dates of Completion
Requests are processed in the order in which they are received through our multi-track processing system.  Requests are divided into two primary tracks--simple (under 50 pages of potentially responsive documents) and complex (over 50 pages of potentially responsive documents).  Complex requests are further divided into medium, large, and extra-large sub-tracks based upon request size.  Simple track requests typically require the least amount of time to process.  Currently, simple track cases average approximately 134 days from the date of receipt for processing.  Our complex requests in the medium processing track are currently averaging 523 days, large processing track are currently averaging approximately 1,335 days, and extra-large processing track are currently averaging 1,875 days for processing.

Respectfully,

Public Information Officer
Record/Information Dissemination Section (RIDS) FBI-Information Management Division
170 Marcel Drive, Winchester, VA 22602-4843
Direct: (540) 868-4593
Fax: (540) 868-4391
Questions E-mail: foipaquestions@fbi.gov<mailto:foipaquestions@fbi.gov>

Do you have further questions about the FOI/PA process? Visit us at http://www.fbi.gov/foia

Please check the status of your request online at https://vault.fbi.gov/fdps-1/@@search-fdps    Status updates are performed on a weekly basis.

Note:  This is a non-emergency email address.  If this is an emergency, please call 911 directly.  If you need to report a tip for immediate action, please contact FBI Tips at http://tips.fbi.gov/ or reach out to your local field office.

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #1413411-000
communications.communication:
Thank you for contacting foipaquestions@fbi.gov.  Please check the status of your FOIPA Request at http://vault.fbi.gov by clicking on "Check Status of Your FOI/PA Request" on the right side of the page, and follow the instructions below.

Check the Status of Your FOIPA Request
If your FOIPA Number is [1234567-0] please enter [1234567-000] into the system. If your FOIPA Number is [1234567-1] please enter [1234567-001] into the system. If you have any questions about the status of your FOIPA request, please e-mail foipaquestions@ic.fbi.gov.

FIND STATUS OF FOIPA- Request statuses are updated weekly

Please enter the whole FOIPA number-Example: [1234567-000]

FOIPA:
Results will show the Request Number, Case Type and Process Description shown below:
FOIPA:
1234567-000

Case Type:
FOIPA

Process Description (Will display the current progress of the request)
The FBI's FOIPA Program is searching the FBI's indices for potentially responsive documents.
You may be contacted via formal letter for all fees and/or negotiation issues that may apply.

NOTE: Recent requests are entered into the FOIPA database in the order that they are received. Before you can check the status, you must have received correspondence assigning a FOIPA request number and the information transferred to the online database. Status information is updated weekly. If a request has been closed within the last six months the online database will display the following: The FOIPA number entered has been closed, and appropriate correspondence has been sent to the address on file.

Estimated Dates of Completion
Requests are processed in the order in which they are received through our multi-track processing system.  Requests are divided into two primary tracks--simple (under 50 pages of potentially responsive documents) and complex (over 50 pages of potentially responsive documents).  Complex requests are further divided into medium, large, and extra-large sub-tracks based upon request size.  Simple track requests typically require the least amount of time to process.  Currently, simple track cases average approximately 138 days from the date of receipt for processing.  Our complex requests in the medium processing track are currently averaging 571 days, large processing track are currently averaging approximately 1,289 days, and extra-large processing track are currently averaging 1,649 days for processing.

Respectfully,

Public Information Officer
FBI - Information Management Division
170 Marcel Drive
Winchester, VA  22602
O: (540) 868-4593
F: (540) 868-4391
E: foipaquestions@fbi.gov<mailto:foipaquestions@fbi.gov>

Do you have further questions about the FOI/PA process? Visit us at http://www.fbi.gov/foia

Please check the status of your request online at https://vault.fbi.gov/fdps-1/@@search-fdps    Status updates are performed on a weekly basis.

Note:  This is a non-emergency email address.  If this is an emergency, please call 911 directly.  If you need to report a tip for immediate action, please contact FBI Tips at http://tips.fbi.gov/ or reach out to your local field office.

title: Records, Peter Gotti (1939 – 2021)

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Records, Peter Gotti (1939 – 2021)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

All records concerning or mentioning Peter Gotti, deceased former boss of the Gambino family of Cosa Nostra. To identify records and rule out duplicate names, Gotti's year of birth was 1939; the Bureau of Prisons lists his registration number as 99109-012.

Gotti is known to be deceased (see attachment); privacy interests are diminished and all records should be released in public interest.

Please conduct a search of the Central Records System, including but not limited to the ELSUR Records System, the Microphone Surveillance (MISUR) Indices, the Physical Surveillance (FISUR) Indices, the Technical Surveillance (TESUR) Indices, and Counterdrug Information Indices System (CIIS), for both main-file records and cross-reference records for all relevant names, individuals, agencies and companies.

If any potentially responsive records have been destroyed and/or transferred to NARA, then I request copies of the destruction or transfer slips as well as any other documentation relating to, mentioning or describing said transfer or destruction, to include but not be limited to confirmation that the Bureau has no other copies of said records.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

T. McElwee

database, please check back at a later date.

title: Survey of New Jersey Open Records Act Resources (City of Union FOIA)

communications.subject: New Jersey Open Public Records Act Request: Survey of New Jersey Open Records Act Resources (City of Union FOIA)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New Jersey Open Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

1. A copy of any budget, accounting, or other records sufficient to show the expenses or resources necessary for the city (including any departments thereof) to respond to public records requests.

2. A copy of the job description for any person (whether employed by the city or any departments thereof) whose primary responsibilities include responding to or managing public records requests. If a separate record identifies the anticipated or actual amount of time the person spends on their duties (i.e., identifying how much of their time is spent on a given subject), please provide that record, as well.

3. Any record sufficient to show the salary of any person (whether employed by the city or any departments thereof) whose primary responsibilities include responding to or managing public records requests.

4. If the city maintains a log of public records requests, please provide a copy of the log dating back to January 1, 2022.

Requests 1-3 are limited to documents generated during or concerning the last fiscal year.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 7 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Adam Steinbaugh

title: ICE Public Affairs Responses to In-Custody Deaths at Aurora, Torrance

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: ICE Public Affairs Responses to In-Custody Deaths at Aurora, Torrance
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

On behalf of the Al Otro Lado #DetentionKills Transparency Initiative, we respectfully request all records created or received by ICE's Office of Public Affairs at the Headquarters, El Paso Field Office, and Denver Field Office levels regarding the deaths in custody of Kesley Dial at CoreCivic's Torrance, New Mexico facility and The GEO Group's Aurora, Colorado facility. Specifically, we seek emails sent or received, calendar entries for appointments to discuss either of the deaths in custody, Teams messages, the contents of SharePoint drive folders regarding ICE's public statements regarding these deaths, and any records relied upon to assert the factual matters in ICE's post-death release statements, posted here: 
https://www.ice.gov/news/releases/brazilian-man-ice-custody-passes-away-new-mexico-hospital?s=09
and here: 
https://www.ice.gov/news/releases/nicaraguan-man-ice-custody-passes-away-colorado-hospital

By definition, the information requested cannot be subject to withholding under Exemption 7A (open investigations), because ICE has already released its core facts publicly.

We seek expedited processing of this request under 6 C.F.R. 5.5(e), and make the following statements under penalty of perjury pursuant to 28 USC 1746 in support thereof: 
1. Both the Torrance in-custody death and the Aurora in-custody death have been met with calls from elected Representatives and Senators for vigorous investigation, based on each facility's documented track record. See https://www.heinrich.senate.gov/newsroom/press-releases/heinrich-leads-request-for-immediate-action-from-ice-to-address-inhumane-unsafe-conditions-for-migrants-at-the-torrance-county-detention-facility and https://crow.house.gov/sites/evo-subsites/crow.house.gov/files/evo-media-document/2022.10.21-final-icedhs-letter_0.pdf. 

2. Both deaths have been the subject of widespread and sustained media attention. 
For Torrance: 
https://www.nytimes.com/2022/09/22/us/politics/aclu-ice-immigration-detention.html
https://sourcenm.com/2022/09/01/brazilian-asylum-seeker-who-died-by-suicide-held-in-horrific-conditions-attorneys-say/
https://nmpoliticalreport.com/2022/08/31/immigrant-advocacy-organizations-seeking-answers-around-brazilian-mans-death-by-suicide-while-in-ice-custody/
https://www.democracynow.org/2022/10/18/headlines/asylum_seekers_at_torrance_ice_jail_claim_retaliation_over_hunger_strike
https://theappeal.org/torrance-detention-center-kesley-vial-brazil/
https://www.santafenewmexican.com/opinion/letters_to_editor/close-torrance-county-ice-facility-now/article_08a7cf58-5705-11ed-b432-1bb650ab5a32.html
https://www.krqe.com/news/crime/man-commits-suicide-in-ice-custody-in-torrance-county/
https://www.democracynow.org/2022/8/29/headlines/asylum_seeker_dies_by_suicide_at_for_profit_ice_jail_in_new_mexico
https://www.abqjournal.com/2528527/webhedline-126.html
https://www.lcsun-news.com/story/news/local/new-mexico/2022/09/30/groups-retaliation-after-migrants-report-torrance-county-detention-center/69530415007/

For Aurora: 
https://www.cpr.org/2022/10/27/colorado-lawmakers-call-for-investigation-into-death-at-aurora-ice-facility/
https://www.cpr.org/2022/11/03/advocates-immigration-customs-enforcement-custody-death/
https://www.9news.com/article/news/local/man-nicaragua-dies-aurora-ice-facility/73-f52d0d45-531c-4e17-a361-1376d887e499
https://www.denver7.com/news/local-news/colorado-lawmakers-call-for-probe-after-detainees-death-at-aurora-ice-facility
https://www.cbsnews.com/colorado/news/melvin-ariel-calero-mendoza-nicaraguan-father-dies-ice-custody-aurora-facility/
https://www.longmontleader.com/local-news/el-comite-wants-answers-to-ice-detention-death-5990654
https://news.yahoo.com/video/nicaraguan-father-two-dies-ice-040542382.html
https://www.newsbreak.com/news/2810691040469/report-details-what-led-up-to-man-s-death-in-aurora-ice-custody

3. In both cases, serious questions have been raised by elected officials as to the circumstances surrounding each person's death, and ICE and its contractors' compliance with mandatory duties surrounding care of detained immigrants. 

Therefore, the requirements of 6 C.F.R. 5.5(e) are satisfied, and expedited processing is proper. 

Thank you for your prompt attention to this important request, and your response within the statutorily required 10-calendar day period! 

#DetentionKills Transparency Initiative
Al Otro Lado

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Andrew Free

communications.subject: RE: ICE FOIA Case Number 2023-ICFO-03462
communications.communication:
12/21/2022Andrew FreeMuckRock News, DEPT MR136588Boston, Massachusetts 02115RE:	ICE FOIA Case Number 2023-ICFO-03462        Dear Requester:This acknowledges receipt of your 11/8/2022, Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request to U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), for all records created or received by ICE's Office of Public Affairs at the Headquarters, El Paso Field Office, and Denver Field Office levels regarding the deaths in custody of Kesley Dial at CoreCivic's Torrance, New Mexico facility and The GEO Group's Aurora, Colorado facility. .  Your request was received in this office on 11/8/2022.After careful review of your FOIA request, we determined that your request is 1) too broad in scope, 2) did not specifically identify the records which you are seeking, or 3) only posed questions to the agency.  Records must be described in reasonably sufficient detail to enable government employees who are familiar with the subject area to locate records without placing an unreasonable burden upon the agency.  For this reason, §5.3(b) of the DHS regulations, 6 C.F.R. Part 5, require that you describe the records you are seeking with as much information as possible to ensure that our search can locate them with a reasonable amount of effort.  Whenever possible, a request should include specific information about each record sought, such as the date, title or name, author, recipients, and subject matter of the records, if known, or the ICE program office you believe created and/or controls the record.  The FOIA does not require an agency to create new records, answer questions posed by requesters, or attempt to interpret a request that does not identify specific records.  Please resubmit your request containing a reasonable description of the records you are seeking.  Upon receipt of a perfected request, you will be advised as to the status of your request.If we do not hear from you within 30 days from the date of this letter, we will assume you are no longer interested in this FOIA request, and the case will be administratively closed.  Please be advised that this action is not a denial of your request and will not preclude you from filing other requests in the future. If you have any questions please contact FOIA Public Liaison Marcus Francis at (866) 633-1182 or the address above.Your request has been assigned reference number 2023-ICFO-03462. Sincerely,ICE-FOIA

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #2023-ICFO-03462
communications.communication:
We appeal the agency’s determination that the request is improper. 

It seeks:

“emails sent or received, calendar entries for appointments to discuss either of the deaths in custody, Teams messages, the contents of SharePoint drive folders regarding ICE's public statements regarding these deaths, and any records relied upon to assert the factual matters in ICE's post-death release statements, posted [on ICE’s website].”

We seek expedited processing of this request for the reasons described in our original submission. 

#DetentionKills Transparency Initiative 
Al Otro Lado

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #2023-ICAP-00243
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

I wanted to follow up on the following Freedom of Information Act request, copied below, and originally submitted on Nov. 8, 2022. Please let me know when I can expect to receive a response.  You had assigned it reference number #2023-ICAP-00243.

Thanks for your help, and let me know if further clarification is needed.

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #2023-ICAP-00243
communications.communication:
You have reached SecureRelease Support.

The purpose of this inbox is to provide technical support for the SecureRelease FOIA Request Portal website (https://www.securerelease.us/).

SecureRelease website support staff are not involved with the processing or prioritization of requests, and this inbox is not monitored by agency personnel.

According to our records, request 2023-ICAP-00243 was not submitted through the SecureRelease Request Portal, therefore, we are unable to provide online status tracking or portal messaging capabilities for this request.

We have CC’ed the ICE FOIA inbox for visibility. To follow up further on this request, please refer to communications you received from the agency for contact instructions or reach out to the agency in the same manner that you submitted your request.

Regards,

SecureRelease™ Support Team
securereleasesupportteam@deloitte.com<mailto:securereleasesupportteam@deloitte.com>
www.securerelease.us<http://www.securerelease.us>

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #2023-ICAP-00243
communications.communication:
Good day,

In regards to 2023-ICAP+00243, we have queried the appropriate component of DHS for responsive records.  If any responsive records are located, they will be reviewed for determination of releasability.  We will process your request as expeditiously as possible.  Upon completion of the processing, all documents that can be released will be made available to you as soon as possible.

Thank you,
ICE FOIA

You are legally required to provide an estimated date on which documents will be produced.

You are legally required to make a determination on this request and inform us of it. 

You are legally required to make records promptly available. 

You have failed to comply with any of these requirements. 

If you have any intention of doing so within the next fourteen days, please inform us. 

Thank you.

Your assertion that “a high number of FOIA requests have been received by the Department” is unsupported by the Department’s own FY22 Chief FOIA Officer Report. In other words, you’re saying a thing that your own data demonstrate is untrue. 

But go off, I guess. 

Thank you, 

Andrew Free

Andrew Free 
MuckRock News, DEPT MR136588 
Boston, Massachusetts 02115 

RE:	ICE FOIA Case Number 2024-ICAP-00071, 2024-ICFO-06913 

Dear Requester: 

The Department of Homeland Security has received your letter appealing the adverse determination of your Freedom of Information Act/Privacy Act (FOIA/PA) request by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement. Your appeal, postmarked or electronically transmitted on 11/22/2023, was received on 12/11/2023. 

The Government Information Law Division acknowledges your appeal request of and is assigning it number 2024-ICAP-00071 for tracking purposes.  Please reference this number in any future communications about your appeal. 

A high number of FOIA/PA requests have been received by the Department.  Accordingly, we have adopted the court-sanctioned practice of generally handling backlogged appeals on a first-in, first-out basis.   While we will make every effort to process your appeal on a timely basis, there may be some delay in resolving this matter.  Should you have any questions concerning the processing of your appeal, please contact Fernando Pineiro Jr., ICE FOIA Office/Public Liaison at (866) 633-1182 or at 500 12th St., SW Washington, DC 20536-5009. 

Sincerely, 
 
Sara Jazayeri

title: Street Cop Training Invoices (Tallahassee Police Department)

communications.subject: Florida Sunshine Law Request: Street Cop Training Invoices (Tallahassee Police Department)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Florida Sunshine Law, I hereby request the following records:

Any records documenting or summarizing expenditures related to the vendor Street Cop Training, a company that hosts conferences for law enforcement officers, between January 1, 2020 and Dec. 1, 2023.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

CJ Ciaramella

communications.communication:

title: Douglas County Sheriff - Drone Program

communications.subject: Nevada Public Records Act Request: Douglas County Sheriff - Drone Program
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Nevada Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

- All UAS (unmanned aerial systems) flight logs from 2023
- All written requests for UAS deployment 2023
- All Part 107 certifications for agency UAS operators 
- All FAA and Nevada Department of Public Safety UAS registrations

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

If a fee is not prescribed by law, the following fees are authorized:  1. Up to 15 cents per one-sided copy for duplicated copies of not more than 14 inches by 8 1/2 inches; 2. No more than an additional 5 cents for each two-sided copy 3. For all other copies, the actual cost of duplication of the public record.” Further, pursuant to Florida Statutes §119.07(4)(d) “if the nature or volume of public records requested to be inspected or copied pursuant to this subsection is such as to require extensive use of information technology resources or extensive clerical or supervisory assistance by personnel of the agency involved, or both, the agency may charge, in addition to the actual cost of duplication, a special service charge, which shall be reasonable and shall be based on the cost incurred for such extensive use of information technology resources or the labor cost of the personnel providing the service that is actually incurred by the agency or attributable to the agency for the clerical and supervisory assistance required, or both.” You can monitor the progress of your request at the link below and you'll receive an email when your request has been completed. Again, thank you for using the Public Records Center. The City is happy to comply with your request, and if there is anything else we may help you with, please let me know. title: Treasury Reserves

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Treasury Reserves
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Hello, I would like to request the following information,
What are the current precious metal reserves of the country? Either by ounce or by pound. I am not asking for a new audit of our reserves just the most up to date information. Can you please include reserve fuel and oil.


This request is not being made for commercial purposes.

There should not be any fees associated with this request but in the event that there are fees, please fulfill my request along with an attached invoice. Delivery via email attachment is preferred and authorized.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Mason C. Turner

title: NARA TS/HD 1.12.24

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: NARA TS/HD 1.12.24
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

You are receiving this correspondence as a request under the Freedom of Information Act, 5 U.S.C. subsection 552. I am requesting the following:

For clarification's sake, I am requesting one memorandum within a larger set of records. The memo is titled "1956 Pol 1 Police Administration (Gen)" and, per the online catalog listing on the National Archives and Records Administration's website, covers prohibition of "the use of truth serum or other hypnotic drugs during investigations." Pull information is as follows:

Record Group: 342
Series: General Correspondence, 1953–1959
File Unit: 1956 Pol 1 Police Administration (Gen)
Entry: P 563
Box/Container: 2
NAID: 68888022

I do not require any additional records from this container or series.

I look forward to your response within 20 working days, as the statute requires. If access to the records I am requesting will take longer, please advise of which tier of processing queue this request falls under and an estimated time frame for processing.

If you deny any or all of this request, please cite each specific exemption you feel justifies the refusal to release the information and notify me of the appeal procedures available to me under the law.

Sincerely,
Robert Skvarla, Jr.

communications.subject: Re: Freedom of Information Act Request: NARA TS/HD 1.12.24
communications.communication:
This is an automated reply to inform you that the National Archives and Records Administration received your email.  

We have received your request and you will receive a response within 20 working days. Please note that submitting duplicate requests will increase wait times.  

If you have any questions, you can call our office at 301-837-3190. You can also visit our web page at www.archives.gov/research/foia.  


Thank you.

communications.subject: National Archives and Records Administration FOIA RD 78518
communications.communication:
Dear Robert Skvarla, Jr.:

I am writing in response to your Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request
of February 12, 2024  for records in the custody of the National Archives
and Records Administration. Your request was received in this office on
February 13, 2024 and assigned FOIA tracking number RD 78518.

You requested access to a  memorandum titled “1956 Pol 1 Police
Administration (Gen)”. My initial assessment is that 1956 Pol 1 Police
Administration (Gen) is the subject of the records, created in September
1956, and consisting of an estimated 3 pages.

These records require review for information protected from release under
the FOIA: https://www.archives.gov/foia/foia-guide#determine.

Your request does not exceed 700 pages, so it is assigned to our first-tier
processing queue. Taking into consideration our existing backlog, we
estimate it will take 39 months to complete processing.

Once we notify you that processing is complete, you may either visit our
College Park, MD facility to view the file at no cost, or order a
reproduction. We charge a minimum fee of $20 for reproduction orders.

You must notify this office of changes to your contact information. If
communication is returned as undeliverable and no return address is
provided, your case will be administratively closed. To change your contact
information or to track the status of your request, please email
specialaccess_foia@nara.gov or call 301-837-3190. Please include your FOIA
tracking number in all communications concerning this request.

If you are not satisfied with our action on this request and would like the
opportunity to discuss our response, you may contact our FOIA Public
Liaison for assistance:


Accessioned Executive Branch Records – Washington, DC Area

FOIA Requester Service Center: 301-837-3190

FOIA Public Liaison: Rebecca Calcagno

8601 Adelphi Road, Room 5500

College Park, MD 20740-6001

dc.foia.liaison@nara.gov

301-837-3190

If you have other questions regarding your request, please contact me
directly.

Sincerely,


Brittanie Sadler
-- 
Brittanie Sadler
Archives Specialist
Special Access and FOIA Program
National Archives and Records Administration
8601 Adelphi Road. Room 3400
College Park, MD 20740-6001
301-837-3270
brittanie.sadler@nara.gov
https://www.archives.gov/research/foia

communications.subject: Re: Freedom of Information Act Request #RD 78518
communications.communication:
Dear Robert Skvarla, Jr.:

I am writing in response to your Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request
of February 12, 2024  for records in the custody of the National Archives
and Records Administration. Your request was received in this office on
February 13, 2024 and assigned FOIA tracking number RD 78518.

You requested access to a  memorandum titled “1956 Pol 1 Police
Administration (Gen)”. My initial assessment is that 1956 Pol 1 Police
Administration (Gen) is the subject of the records, created in September
1956, and consisting of an estimated 3 pages.

I completed a line-by-line review of the records you requested. They are
released in full and a summary is available below:

Records Requested

Total Pages

Pages Released in Full

Air Force Memo

3

3

As a courtesy, our office can provide  each requester with free copies of up
to 20 pages total per fiscal year. To date you have received 17 pages that
count toward your free 20 pages for the 2024 fiscal year.


Attached are the complimentary copies of the requested file.

If you are not satisfied with my action on this request, you have the right
to file an administrative appeal within ninety (90) calendar days from the
date of this letter. Appeals must be in writing and may be delivered by
regular U.S. mail or by email. By filing an appeal, you preserve your
rights under the Freedom of Information Act and present the deciding agency
with an opportunity to review your request and reconsider its decision. If
you submit your appeal by regular mail, it should be addressed to the
Deputy Archivist of the United States (ND), National Archives and Records
Administration, 8601 Adelphi Road, Room 4200, College Park, Maryland
20740-6001. Both the letter and envelope should be clearly marked “FOIA
Appeal.” If you submit your appeal by email, please send it to foia@nara.gov,
addressed to the Deputy Archivist, with the words “FOIA Appeal” in the
subject line. If you exercise your right to appeal, please explain why you
believe this response does not meet the requirements of the Freedom of
Information Act. All communications concerning this request should
reference your FOIA tracking number.

If you would like the opportunity to discuss my response and attempt to
resolve your dispute without initiating the appeals process, you may
contact our FOIA Public Liaison for assistance:

Accessioned Executive Branch Records – Washington, DC Area

FOIA Requester Service Center: 301-837-3190

FOIA Public Liaison: Rebecca Calcagno

8601 Adelphi Road, Room 5500

College Park, MD 20740-6001

dc.foia.liaison@nara.gov

301-837-3190

You may also contact the Office of Government Information Services (OGIS),
the Federal FOIA Ombudsman’s office, for assistance. OGIS offers mediation
services to help resolve disputes between FOIA requesters and Federal
agencies. The contact information for OGIS is:

Office of Government Information Services

National Archives and Records Administration

8601 Adelphi Road–OGIS

College Park, MD 20740-6001

Email: ogis@nara.gov

https://www.archives.gov/ogis

Phone: 202-741-5770 or 1-877-684-6448

This concludes the processing of your request. If you have questions
concerning my review, please contact me directly.


*Thank you for your patience!*

Sincerely,

Brittanie Sadler
-- 
Brittanie Sadler
Archives Specialist
Special Access and FOIA Program
National Archives and Records Administration
8601 Adelphi Road. Room 3400
College Park, MD 20740-6001
301-837-3270

title: VT police data collection (2017-2022) (Essex Police Department)

communications.subject: Vermont Public Records Act Request: VT police data collection (2017-2022) (Essex Police Department)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Vermont Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

1. the total number of use of force incidents reported from 2017-2022, separated by year.

2. the total number of use of force incidents, separated by type of force and year, from 2017-2022 (for example, information that specifies the number of taser incidents in 2022, baton incidents in 2022, taser incidents in 2021, baton incidents in 2021, etc.)

3. the total number of civilian complaints against law enforcement that were reported and the total number sustained from 2017-2022, separated by year.

4. the total number of civilian complaints alleging law enforcement use of excessive force that were reported and the total number sustained from 2017-2022, separated by year.

5. the total number of civilian complaints alleging biased policing or racial profiling that were reported and the total number sustained from 2017-2022, separated by year.

6. the total number of civilian complaints alleging criminal conduct that were reported and the total number sustained from 2017-2022, separated by year.

7. the total number of officer-involved shootings from 2017-2022, both fatal and non-fatal, separated by year.

8. the total number of people who police used force against in 2022, broken down by race/ethnicity.

When available, I would appreciate being sent individualized data in this request in spreadsheet format. If individualized data are unavailable, please send information that includes aggregate statistics for the item instead.

Note that my requests for civilian complaints are specifically for civilian complaints, please do not include complaints filed by one officer/the department against another officer.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 3 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Samuel Sinyangwe

communications.communication:
March 11, 2024


MuckRock News
Dept MR 160085
263 Hungtington Ave
Boston, MA 02115
E: 160085-47122433@requests.muckrock.com<mailto:160085-47122433@requests.muckrock.com>

RE:          Acknowledgement of Records Request                  Ticket ID# 24-676


Dear Michael Locke,
We have received your public records request.

Your request will be processed in accordance with the Florida Public Records Law.

Please be advised there are potentially fees to cover the cost of reproduction, including copier expenses, supplies and staff time associated with all requests.  You will be advised as soon as possible regarding estimated costs.  Payment will be due in advance by check or money order made payable to the School Board of Brevard County.  If the actual cost is more than the estimate, your records will be released when payment in full has been received.  If the actual cost is less than the estimate, a check for reimbursement will be requested and mailed to you.

PLEASE NOTE: Not all completed public records are in a digitized format.  To receive a digitized version of a redacted record may require additional time and resources, resulting in additional expense.

You will be notified if records are exempt from public disclosure.  Under public records laws, the district is not obliged to create a new document or records in response to a request for public records.  Likewise, the district will not acquire computer software for the sole purpose of providing access or delivery of public records that are accessible by other means.

If you have any questions, please contact me at recordsrequest@brevardschools.org<mailto:recordsrequest@brevardschools.org>.

Holly Christmas
Florida Certified Records Manager
Brevard Public Schools
Division of Government and Community Relations
2700 Judge Fran Jamieson Way
Viera, FL  32940
321 633-1000 x11453
[BPSLogoColor]

communications.subject: RE: Florida Sunshine Law Request #24-676
communications.communication:
Thank you for your response. To clarify, I submitted this request in my personal capacity as a parent, not on behalf of MuckRock or for any commercial purpose. Under the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA), as a parent I have a right to access my child's educational records, which includes communications between school staff that relate to my child.

Please let me know if you need any additional information from me to process this request, such as a copy of my ID or custody paperwork demonstrating my parental rights. I would be happy to provide that documentation. If there are any fees associated with searching for or copying these records, please inform me before fulfilling my request.

I understand you must comply with FERPA, but that law also ensures parental access to student records, with limited exceptions. FERPA requires redacting personally identifiable information about other students, but communications relating to my child should be provided to me, with appropriate redactions if needed.

If any responsive records are located, I would prefer to receive them electronically via email if possible, to avoid copying costs. If records are withheld or redacted, please cite the specific statutory exemption that forms the basis for the denial and advise me of the appeal procedures available to me under the law.

Thank you in advance for your assistance with my request. Please let me know if you have any questions or need further information from me.

Sincerely,
Michael Locke

communications.communication:
Dear CJ Ciaramella: 
Your request was received in this office on 4/16/2024 and given the reference number M000376-041624 for tracking purposes. Your request mentioned: 
"To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Florida Sunshine Law, I hereby request the following records:

Any records documenting or summarizing expenditures related to the vendor Street Cop Training, a company that hosts conferences for law enforcement officers, between January 1, 2020 and Dec. 1, 2023.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

CJ Ciaramella

--- Please respond above this line --- 

Good afternoon: The records you requested are attached. 
One VSO deputy attended "The Street Smart Cop/Pro-Active Patrol Tactics" in July 2021 in Jacksonville, FL. 
One VSO deputy attended "Florida Case Law That All Cops Need to Know" in January 2022 in Tavares, FL. 
Five VSO deputies attended "Unmasking Facial Expressions" and "Body Language for Law Enforcement" at our Training facility in Daytona Beach in January 2023. 
At that time in January 2023, our training personnel were evaluating the course content to determine whether it could be a useful component of our program. This was prior to learning of the details that have been reported by the New Jersey Comptroller's Office and others. VSO has not hosted or attended any "Street Cop Training" events since the January 2023 event.

title: Jose Mena - Records

communications.subject: Hawaii Uniform Information Practices Act Request: Jose Mena - Records
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Hawaii Uniform Information Practices Act, I hereby request the following records:

Regarding former DPS officer Jose A Mena, please provide:
- Employment history at DPS, including job title and start/end date of each position
- Records sufficient to show the respective dates and type of leave of any personal time off, vacation days, personal days, furlough days, paid/unpaid leave, and any other time off taken for the dates between August 18, 2019 and December 15, 2021.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Rose Terse

The City has reviewed your request for copies of public information. Section 552.2615 of the Texas Government Code requires that a governmental body provide a requestor with an itemized statement of estimated charges if charges for public information will exceed $40. 
Total: $54.00 
Please note that under the Texas Public Information Act these records are also available for inspection. Although there may be some costs associated with inspecting, these costs are likely to be significantly less than those associated with receiving copies of the responsive records. You may visit our offices during business hours and inspect the documents. It is strongly suggested that you make an appointment. 

You, the requestor, must respond to this notice in writing, either by mail, in person, by facsimile, or by electronic mail. If your written response is not received within ten business days after the date this statement was sent, your request will be considered to have been automatically withdrawn. In your response, you must state that you:

Sincerely,

title: Amtrak Board of Directors - Meeting Agendas and Minutes | Nov 2023

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Amtrak Board of Directors - Meeting Agendas and Minutes | Nov 2023
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

The agenda and minutes for any meeting of Amtrak's Board of Directors that occurred in November 2023, including the meetings that were held on November 30th, 2023.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Ben Heckscher

title: Operation Payback

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Operation Payback
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Files mentioning "Operation Payback" or "Operation Avenge Assange," a series of cyber campaigns and attacks by the hacker collective Anonymous, which resulted in cyber attacks on PayPal, PostFinance, EveryDNS, the website of U.S. Senator Joe Lieberman, as well as Visa and Mastercard.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Emma Best

    Emma Best

    Upload documents directly:
    https://www.muckrock.com/accounts/agency_login/federal-bureau-of-investigation-10/operation-payback-66571/?uuid-login=3dff9bcd-01c7-44a5-8e56-13326a245a68&email=efoia%40subscriptions.fbi.gov#agency-reply

** 

Please be advised that efoia@subscriptions.fbi.gov is a no-reply email
address. Questions regarding your FOIA request may be directed to
foipaquestions@fbi.gov. If you have received a FOIPA request number, please
include this in all correspondence concerning your request. Please note eFOIPA
requests are processed in the order that they are received. If you have not
received a FOIPA request number, your request is in the process of being
opened at which time it will be assigned a FOIPA request number and
correspondence will be forthcoming.

** 

Upon receipt of your FOIPA request number, you may check the status of your
FOIPA request on the FBI’s electronic FOIA Library (The Vault) on the FBI’s
public website, http://vault.fbi.gov by clicking on the ‘Check Status of Your
FOI/PA Request tool’ link. Status updates are performed on a weekly basis. If
you receive a comment that your FOIPA request number was not located in the
database, please check back at a later date.

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request: Operation Payback
communications.communication:
Thank you for considering narrowing the scope of your request.  Your email will be forwarded to our negotiation team and a representative will be in contact.  Please allow 2-3 weeks for this initial contact.

Respectfully,

Public Information Officer
Record/Information Dissemination Section (RIDS) FBI-Information Management Division
170 Marcel Drive, Winchester, VA 22602-4843
Direct: (540) 868-4593
Fax: (540) 868-4391
Questions E-mail: foipaquestions@fbi.gov<mailto:foipaquestions@fbi.gov>

Do you have further questions about the FOI/PA process? Visit us at http://www.fbi.gov/foia

Please check the status of your request online at https://vault.fbi.gov/fdps-1/@@search-fdps    Status updates are performed on a weekly basis.

Note:  This is a non-emergency email address.  If this is an emergency, please call 911 directly.  If you need to report a tip for immediate action, please contact FBI Tips at http://tips.fbi.gov/ or reach out to your local field office.

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #1425709-000
communications.communication: Wow, you don't do ANYTHING in the statutory time limits, do you?

communications.subject: FW: Freedom of Information Act Request: Operation Payback
communications.communication:
Good morning Ms. Best,

The Public Information Officer indicated that you would be interested in eliminating the court documents from this request. Doing so would remove approximately 1685 pages. There are approximately 18,649 potentially responsive pages, so removing the court documents alone wouldn't be enough to move the request from the extra-large track (> 8,000 pages). We would be happy to make this reduction for you, but would ask that you consider making a further reduction to move the request into one of the faster tracks. Would you possibly be willing to reduce the request to up to 950 pages to move the request into the medium track? You are always welcome to request additional material once a release has been made. We could take the first 950 pages, the last 950, or split between the beginning and end of the file if you would like.

Please let us know how you would like to move forward.

Best regards,

FBI FOIA Negotiation Team
Information Management Division
fbi.foipa.negotiation@fbi.gov<mailto:fbi.foipa.negotiation@fbi.gov>
540-868-1695

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #1425709-000
communications.communication:
Good afternoon Ms. Best,

We can certainly do that. We'll eliminate the court documents and go forward with the remaining material for approximately 16,956 pages.

Best regards,

FBI FOIA Negotiation Team
Information Management Division
fbi.foipa.negotiation@fbi.gov<mailto:fbi.foipa.negotiation@fbi.gov>

communications.subject: FW: Freedom of Information Act Request #1425709-000
communications.communication:
Good morning Ms. Best,

There are a couple of items to address before we can move forward with processing this request. First, we have a revised total for the court documents -  1789 pages, rather than 1685 pages. Also, we need to have an agreement from you to pay for the remaining pages before we proceed. The total, should all the remaining pages be released is now $505 (34 CDs at $15 each, less $5 credit for the first CD). This is an estimate; some information may not be responsive to your subject, while some may be withheld in full pursuant to FOIA/Privacy Act exemptions. Actual charges could be less, so no payment is due at this time. Payment information will be included with your release letter.

Best regards,

FBI FOIA Negotiation Team
Information Management Division
fbi.foipa.negotiation@fbi.gov<mailto:fbi.foipa.negotiation@fbi.gov>
540-868-1695

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #1425709-000
communications.communication:
You should receive payment soon. Thank you for your patience. I understand it must be difficult to have to wait an entire week. 

I've been waiting over nine months. All but the last week was due to delays by your office. For instance, you ask me a question, I respond that day, four days later you tell me to "allow 2-3 weeks" for an initial response. I appreciate your diligence in following up, but thought you might want some perspective on the delays at play.

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #1425709-000
communications.communication:
Dear Ms. Best,

I believe there's been a misunderstanding. We only need you to agree to charges up to $505. No payment is owed at this time. Do we understand correctly that you agree to pay up to $505 for processing this request? As mentioned previously, this is an estimate; some information may not be responsive to your subject, while some may be withheld in full pursuant to FOIA/Privacy Act exemptions. Actual charges could be less, so no payment is due at this time. Payment information will be included with your release letter.

Best regards,

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #1425709-000
communications.communication:
And now I have egg on my face.

I absolutely misread the message. Some agencies (especially those I don't have a history with) require 50% up front. When I scrolled up and skimmed the message... I apologize, and thank you for clarifying.

Yes, I agree to pay up to $505 in duplication fees for this request. 

If, in the review process, å new way to reduce the scope occurs the analyst processing it (saving time for them and money for me), I'm happy to consider it.

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #1425709-000
communications.communication:
Good morning Ms. Best,

No worries, sometimes we misunderstand each other. All is well and thanks for the clarification. We’ll go ahead and make the current reduction, removing the court documents and if there are any other reductions that seem sensible when the request is being processed, we’ll give you a shout and figure that out at the time.

You should receive a letter from us in the next week or so confirming the removal of the court documents.

Thanks again and best regards,

FBI FOIA Negotiation Team
Information Management Division
fbi.foipa.negotiation@fbi.gov<mailto:fbi.foipa.negotiation@fbi.gov>
540-868-1695

title: IAPro internal investigations (Redmond Police Department)

communications.subject: Washington Public Records Act Request: IAPro internal investigations (Redmond Police Department)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

I request the listing of internal investigations in IA Pro with columns:
 Occurred date    Case/CAD/Incident No    Employee ID/Serial number    First name    Last name    Date hired    Incident type    Allegation    Directive    Finding    Finding date    Action taken    Employee Type 

I request the listing be provided in Excel format so I can easily sort/filter it. Redactions should be done in Excel.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Rose Terse

title: Survey of New Jersey Open Records Act Resources (Municipal Clerk)

communications.subject: New Jersey Open Public Records Act Request: Survey of New Jersey Open Records Act Resources (Municipal Clerk)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New Jersey Open Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

1. A copy of any budget, accounting, or other records sufficient to show the expenses or resources necessary for the city (including any departments thereof) to respond to public records requests.

2. A copy of the job description for any person (whether employed by the city or any departments thereof) whose primary responsibilities include responding to or managing public records requests. If a separate record identifies the anticipated or actual amount of time the person spends on their duties (i.e., identifying how much of their time is spent on a given subject), please provide that record, as well.

3. Any record sufficient to show the salary of any person (whether employed by the city or any departments thereof) whose primary responsibilities include responding to or managing public records requests.

4. If the city maintains a log of public records requests, please provide a copy of the log dating back to January 1, 2022.

Requests 1-3 are limited to documents generated during or concerning the last fiscal year.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 7 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Adam Steinbaugh

communications.subject: New Message :: R000958-091023
communications.communication:
--- Please respond above this line --- 

This email shall acknowledge receipt of your Freedom of Information Law (“FOIL”) request, directed to the MTA. 

Please be advised that the MTA FOIL Unit receives a high volume of FOIL requests ranging from simple to complex requests and all documents and records require review prior to disclosure. As a result, documents and records will not be immediately available. Under certain circumstances of the request, such as, the number of documents requested, their format, their availability, the time it takes to identify and locate the requested records and review and redact any information that cannot be disclosed pursuant to FOIL, the time it takes to assemble the documents, and other factors, processing and response times may be delayed. Since the time and effort required to complete a response can vary significantly, the MTA endeavors to complete each request in a time period that is reasonable under the circumstances of the request. 

We are currently reviewing your request and anticipate responding within approximately forty-five (45) business days. 

Should it become necessary to inquire further regarding this request, please send a reply which will update this request and refer to your FOIL reference number in your correspondence. 

MTA FOIL Unit

communications.subject: New Message :: R000958-091023
communications.communication:
--- Please respond above this line --- 

Please be advised that your FOIL request is requiring additional time to respond to as the documents that are found to be potentially responsive are undergoing an analysis for responsiveness, legal privileges and applicable FOIL exemptions, pursuant to NYPOL §87(2) of the FOIL statute. Please allow an additional thirty (30) business days as we anticipate providing a response on or before January 2, 2024. 

We apologize for any inconvenience. 

MTA FOIL Unit

We apologize for any inconvenience. 

MTA FOIL Unit

communications.subject: Ref: F-2023-10276, Freedom of Information Act Acknowledgement
communications.communication:
**THIS EMAIL BOX IS NOT MONITORED, PLEASE DO NOT REPLY TO THIS EMAIL.**  08/08/2023 Ref:F-2023-10276 Dear Mr.Topic: This is an acknowledgment to your June 27, 2023, Freedomof Information Act (FOIA) (5 U.S.C. § 552) and Privacy Act request (5 U.S.C. §552a) received by the U.S. Department of State, Office of Information Programsand Services. You are seeking electronic records containing the term "LIVGolf." The date range is from June 1, 2023, through June 15, 2023, Unless you advise otherwise, we willtreat as non-responsive any compilations of publicly available news reports andany publicly available documents not created by the U.S. government, such asmass-distribution emails from news media. This Office assigned your request the above reference number andplaced it in the complex processing track where it will be processed as quicklyas possible.  See22 CFR §171.11(h). This Office will not beable to respond within the 20 days provided by the statute due to “unusualcircumstances.”  See 5 U.S.C. §552(a)(6)(B)(i)-(iii).  In this instance,the unusual circumstances include the need to search for and collect requestedrecords from other Department offices or Foreign Service posts. If you have any questions regarding your request, would like to narrow the scope or arrange an alternativetime frame to speed its processing, or would like an estimated date ofcompletion, please contact our FOIA Requester Service Center or our FOIA PublicLiaison by email at FOIAstatus@state.gov or telephone at 202-261-8484. Additionally,you may contact the Office of Government Information Services (OGIS) at theNational Archives and Records Administration to inquire about the FOIAmediation services they offer.  Thecontact information for OGIS is as follows: Office of Government InformationServices, National Archives and Records Administration, 8601 Adelphi Road-OGIS,College Park, Maryland 20740-6001, email at ogis@nara.gov ; telephone at 202-741-5770; tollfree at 1-877-684-6448; or facsimile at 202-741-5769. 
For a faster response, you may contact us by email at . (mailto:foiarequest@state.gov) foiarequest@state.gov In your email correspondence, please reference the requestidentification number in the subject line. **THIS EMAIL BOX IS NOT MONITORED, PLEASE DO NOT REPLY TO THIS EMAIL.**

communications.subject: FOIA Case 10276 Clarification
communications.communication: Mr. Matthew Topic, This is in regard to yourFreedom of Information Act (FOIA) request F-2023-10276 stating your interest in“request your electronic records dated June 1 through June 15, 2023, containingthe term "LIV Golf”,”. To better enable us in processing your request, we ask thatyou provide some additional context regarding the information you are seekingregarding “electronic records”. Do you mean digital media such as photographsand videos or were you referring to emails, electronic memos, correspondence,etc? We haveattached a copy of your initial FOIA request, for convenience. We kindlyask that you provide a response within 10 business days of the date of thisemail.  If we do not hear from you by January 15th, we will assume you areno longer interested in this information, and we will administratively closeyou request. Regards, DestineeMcGhee FOIA Analyst Department of State A/GIS/IPS/CR (Charleston)

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #CL-2024-00086
communications.communication:
Hello Kellie,

I am hoping you can help me figure out what is going on with this request. I have received quite a few follow up emails from the DOS, all of them referencing various tracking numbers. This is confusing as the first tracking number given for this request on 6/27/2023 was: F-2023-10276. Below is a listing of each tracking number referenced in follow up emails and the dates I received them. 

CL-2023-00156 --7/28/2023 
CL-2023-00175 --11/6/2023
CL-2023-00178 --11/6/2023
CL-2023-00182 --11/6/2023
CL-2023-00194 --11/6/2023

Please help clarify which requests those tracking numbers are for and why these emails are being sent to this specific request.

Thank You,

MuckRock Staff

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #CL-2024-00086
communications.communication:
Dear Mr. Topic,


You have contacted the FOIA Public Liaison at the Department of State.  The FOIA Public Liaison assists requesters in reducing delays, increasing transparency and the understanding of the status of requests, and assists in the resolution of disputes of their Freedom of Information Act Requests.  This is in response to your e-mail concerning your request, F-2023-10276.

I researched your request and can verify that it was closed on February 29, 2024, when a response letter was e-mailed to you from Destinee McGhee. I have attached a copy of the correspondence.

In regard to the additional CL case numbers that you reference, the only case associated with you is F-2023-10276.  Those automated messages appear to have been generated in error. You should not receive any additional correspondence regarding any CL cases.

I hope you find this information helpful.

Sincerely,


U.S. Department of State
FOIA Program Manager/FOIA Public Liaison
Office of Information Programs and Services
